Award.AbstractNarration: All cells need to translocate proteins into and across hydrophobic membranes to interact with their environment. Most proteins are translocated in an unfolded conformation by the Sec pathway via a universally conserved proteinaceous pore. A number of non-conserved accessory components, which are distinct in bacteria and eukaryotes, are also necessary for efficient transport via this pathway. Surprisingly, the archaeal Sec machinery contains a combination of homologs of bacterial and eukaryotic Sec components, which raises questions regarding the mechanism of translocation in archaea. In addition, in bacteria and yeast, distinct translocation ATPases are required to provide energy for protein transport, yet no archaeal homolog of either of these ATPases has been identified. Thus, the energetics driving the net unidirectional movement of proteins through the archaeal Sec pore remains unknown. The goal of this project is to isolate and characterize archaeal Sec translocation mutants in the model haloarchaeon Haloferax volcanii using two complementary genetic selection strategies. Importantly, these selections have the potential to identify novel Sec components, including components that are unique to archaea (such as a novel translocation ATPase) as well as components that have bacterial and/or eukaryotic homologs, which were not previously known to participate in Sec translocation. Together, this research is likely to further the knowledge of the Sec translocation pathway in all domains of life. Moreover, a better understanding of archaea, which often inhabit "extreme" environments, will allow the investigator to define the boundaries of biological processes in the biosphere, and has the potential to reveal information about the origin and evolution of the three domains of life. This project is fostering the training of students at all levels. Undergraduate students interested in education are doing out reach as part of a university course to intercity schools to demonstrate basic principles of microbial research.

Research Interests

As many critical cellular processes involve proteins that perform their functions in the extracytoplasmic environment, protein transport mechanisms naturally evolved to facilitate the movement of secreted proteins from the cytoplasm, where they are produced, to the cell surface.  Among the most important and best studied of these protein transport mechanisms are the Sec pathway, a universally conserved pathway found in all species that transports proteins to the cell surface in an unfolded conformation, and the Twin arginine transport (Tat) pathway, a pathway found in many bacterial and archaeal species, but not in eukaryotes, that transports a significant portion of the secreted proteins of some species to the cell surface in a folded conformation (Fig. 1).  During protein translation the presence of N-terminal Sec or Tat signal sequences target the corresponding protein for translocation across the cytoplasmic membrane. Although some proteins, such as toxins, are released into the extracellular environment, most remain associated with the cell surface. 

The research focus of our lab is the study of protein transport in archaea, prokaryotes having Sec machinery that appears to most closely resemble that of eukaryotes rather than bacteria, although  some aspects of protein transport are very similar in the two prokaryotic domains, perhaps related to their comparable morphologies. During the most recent NSF funding period, we designed experiments that allowed us to tentatively identify previously unknown protein transport components in the model archaeon Haloferax volcanii, two of which we are currently characterizing.

Besides studying the components and mechanisms of the protein transport pathways, we have also characterized the scope of the diversity of H. volcanii Sec and Tat substrates and begun determining the functions for several of these substrates. Characterization of the diversity of transported substrates included the determination of ultimate subcellular localizations and the specification of post-translational modifications, including the identification of the components involved in these modifications. We also performed in vivo analyses that generated results that allowed us to develop novel subcellular localization prediction programs as well as improve upon existing programs, which allowed us to identify proteins that may be novel components of the H. volcanii protein transport system. Further systematic evaluation of our in vivo and in silico data revealed intriguing patterns suggesting that evolutionary pressures may have determined the particular transport pathway or surface anchoring mechanisms, or both, used for specific substrates. Finally, while we were primarily focused on developing a more complete understanding of protein transport in archaea, the data collected in these studies have also been invaluable in developing an approach to predicting the subcellular localization of proteins in bacteria, including important human pathogens.
